awd_abstract_narration:
Conversation among members of a group is a basic form of language use. It likely played a key role as languages evolved and it continues to play important roles in children's language acquisition and adult communication.  Group communication is typical of a variety of high-stakes settings, including classroom education and business teams, yet surprisingly little is known about what makes communication in groups successful. One determinant of success is the ability to appreciate the perspective of the other person or people in the conversation. Basic communicative exchanges such as asking a question require calculations about what other people know. For example, if you want to know the answer to a question such as "Where is the gas meter?" it is first necessary to determine who is likely to know the answer in order to ask the appropriate person (e.g., a plumber is likely to know, but a young child is not). Keeping track of who knows what also allows us to navigate social relationships effectively. For example, if you once tell your friend "My son is getting married in June," it is usually communicating good news.  If you repeat the same information to the same friend several times, it may instead signal anxiety, uncertainty, or disbelief. This project examines how people take into account the knowledge and perspective of other people in communicative settings and examines conversations among groups of three or more individuals, each of whom brings a different set of beliefs and knowledge to the conversation. 

Graduate and undergraduate students will have opportunities to participate in laboratory research and high school students and elderly individuals from the community will be involved in laboratory activities through community outreach programs. The results of studies on conversation will not only advance understanding of psychological and linguistic processes but can also be used to advance computer dialog systems (such as Siri). 

The proposed work uses methods established by the principal investigator to examine key open questions regarding language use in communicative settings. The idea is that conversational partners serve as contextual memory cues, supporting the partner-specificity of language use. This people-as-contexts (PAC) idea is used as a framework (1) to evaluate candidate hypotheses regarding the mechanisms supporting perspective-taking in multiparty conversation; (2) to test predictions concerning the binding of partners to language and generalization to new contexts; and (3) to examine how adaptation scales up to multiparty conversation. Predictions derived from the theory are tested in the domains of audience design and syntactic adaptation.

por.por_cntn:
The central aim of this work is to understand if and how the way that we use language is shaped by the people we are talking to. This work draws on insights from the fields of cognitive psychology and psycholinguistics, to understand the role of learning and memory in the way language is flexibly used differently depending on who it is we are talking to, and what we've learned about them. The ways that we change the way we use language based on what we know about our conversational partner is broadly known as audience design, or alternatively, perspective-taking. This work examines perspective-taking processes in multiple domains. New empirical findings advanced theory in domains (1) and (2) below. Additionally raw data collected in this award were shared publically, and in turn used to develop novel quantitative methods for analyzing eye-tracking data (3).

(1) This work tested candidate hypotheses regarding the cognitive mechanisms that support perspective-taking in conversation, with special focus on multiparty conversations, that is, conversations where multiple people are talking to each other. Very little prior work had examined how it is that we keep track of multiple other people in multiparty conversation. This is somewhat surprising considering that many every-day activities involve multiparty conversation, including family dinners, teaching in a classroom setting, and working with a team in the workplace. We found that people can keep track of how much other people know about a given topic of conversation, even in groups up to 8 people (Yoon & Brown-Schmidt, 2019a, 2019b; McKinley, et al., 2017). These findings suggest that when speaking to a group of individuals, the speaker may naturally adjust what they say based on the average knowledge of the group, raising intriguing questions as to whether this type of multiparty audience design benefits learning across achievement levels or perspectives.

(2) This work tested predictions of the people-as-contexts hypothesis concerning the way information about other people is remembered in conversation, and how this guides conversation. The theoretical framework was discussed in a theory paper (Brown-Schmidt & Heller, 2018), and key findings include evidence that partner engagement in conversation mediated perspective-taking (Craycraft & Brown-Schmidt, 2018), and that the consistency of partner cues was an important factor in contextually sensitive use of language (Ryskin, et al., 2019). We found that people have good memory for the contexts of language use, including which partner they have talked to before about a given topic (Ahn & Brown-Schmidt, 2020), and what they've discussed in the past (Yoon & Brown-Schmidt, 2021; Zimmerman, et al. 2020). We also find that listeners maintain some degree of uncertainty about what was said over time, allowing them to go back and revise a prior interpretation of speech (Brown-Schmidt & Toscano, 2017; Falandays, et al., 2020).

(3) De-identified data collected on this award was shared on the Open Science Framework, which is a public repository for scientific data. In collaboration with a quantitative methodologist, the PI used eye-tracking data collected on this award to develop two new quantitative models for the analysis of eye-tracking data (Cho, et al., 2018; Cho, et al., 2020). The PI wrote a separate paper summarizing and explaining how to use these models for a substantive audience (Brown-Schmidt, et al., 2020).

Altogether, 11 empirical papers, many conference presentations, and 3 quantitative papers were produced based on data collected in this award. In addition to this intellectual merit, this award supported the training of 6 graduate students, 34 undergraduate students including REU participants. Of the student trainees, 20% were members of groups traditionally underrepresented in science, and 86% were of female or non-binary gender. Multiple trainees were students with disability who worked in the lab on this research. Two undergraduate trainees who collected data as a part of an independent research project went on to publish the data collected on this award in peer-reviewed journals, and two more trainees presented their data at a conference. The broader impacts of this work included training all students in the scientific method, including best practices in research, ethical treatment of human participants, data collection, coding, analysis, statistics, and writing for an academic audience. Trainees learned how to use specific equipment (eye-tracking hardware) and computer software (Matlab, SPSS, R statistics, Praat, Photoshop, and Excel). Data and Matlab code were shared publicly, and multiple members of the scientific community were personally trained by the PI in the use of novel quantitative techniques, the use of Matlab scripts for collecting eye-tracking data, and for data analysis. Multiple youtube videos were created to disseminate this work for the public, and the PI also teaches findings from this work in her classes.
